ter? A. On the 7th of April I gave an account to sergeant Golding—I went to Bow-street, I think, on the 18th, but I was at the inquest before that, on the 11th, I believe—the inspector of police was present—I gave the account I have to-day about the mole on her neck.

ELIZABETH CHRISTIE . I live on the first-floor at No. 18, South-street. I knew Mrs. Good—she lived in the kitchen—I saw her last on Sunday, the 3rd of April, at twelve o'clock at noon—she was not then dressed to go out—I can swear to this bonnet as her property—I altered the bow for her nine months ago—I have frequently seen her wear it, and am quite sure it is hers—this dress is hers, and this handkerchief—this guard I never saw her without, she wore it round her neck, and this key corre
sponds with the door-key—I am quite certain of the guard—I believe she kept her keys on it—I have seen the prisoner come to visit her, for the last two years, two or three times a week, sometimes more—I did not see him on the Monday; I heard his voice, and saw him on Tuesday evening, the 5th of April—I heard somebody come in at the street-door—I went down, and called out, "Who is there?"—he said, "Me"—I said, "Who is me?"—he said "Good"—I went down stairs further, knowing Mrs. Good had been robbed about a year and a half before, to see who it was—I knew his voice when I went further down—there was a little boy showing him a light—I said, "Is that your little boy, Mr. Good?"—he said, "No, my little boy is in the country with his mother"—the boy's back was towards me, or I should have known him—I am sure this was Tuesday—he said, "We are at a ball this evening"—he repeated that two or three times—he was unlocking the door—he did not stay long, but he went to the landlady—after that I went further down stairs, and put my hand on the prisoner's shoulder, to speak to him, and saw the little boy then—I have seen Mrs. Good's neck uncovered when she has been washing, and observed a dark mole, above the collar-bone, on the right side of the neck.

Cross-examined. Q. You have seen Good with her? A. Yes—I have seen them go out on a Sunday together—I have opened the street-door to him—he has said, "Is my wife at home?"—he behaved with the greatest kindness towards her—I have heard him say, when going away, "Good bye, my dear, take care of yourself"—I thought him very fond of her.

GEORGE JAKES . I drive a hackney-cab. On the night of the 6th of April my cab stood near Grosvenor-place—I was hired by the prisoner, about half-past eleven o'clock, to drive him to South-street, Manchester
square, opposite No. 18—he had a small bundle with him—we had a dis
pute about the fare—he gave me is—the fare was 1s. 4d.—I got 2d. more—I said that would not do, I must have the other 2d.—he told me to come over to the public-house—we went to the Bedford Arms, and he called for half a pint of porter.

RICHARD SALMON . I am pot-man at the Bedford Arms, South-street. On Wednesday night, the 6th of April, I saw the prisoner there—I had seen him before that about South-street)—he came to my house and had a glass of ale, and the cabman a pint of porter—he then asked mistress to

lend him & screw-driver, saying he had left his key behind him, and wanted to get into his apartment—she lent him one—I went with him, to bring it back, to No. 18, South-street—Mr. Brown let him into the house—I went down to the kitchen with him—I drew the staple of the door by his direc
tion, and then went away.

JOHN BROWN . I am landlord of No. 18, South-street. I let the pri
soner in on the night of the 6th of April—I believe he stopped there till about half-past five in the morning, when I heard a cab drive away.

HENRY LITTLEBOY . I drive a cab. On the morning of the 7th of April I was in Paddington-street—the prisoner fetched me from there and or
dered me to drive to Charing-cross, but in going along he said to Whit
comb-street—he had a bed, a large box, and a small one, and a hat-box—I took them up at No. 18, South-street, and drove down to Sheppard's livery stables—he took all the things out there—I left him in the street with them near the livery stables.

JAMES OSBORNE . I drive a cab, I was on the stand near the Union Club-house, on the morning of the 7th of April, between a quarter and twenty minutes to six, I was called to drive to Whitcomb-street, which I did, and saw the prisoner with a bundle, a bed, a large trunk, a small box, and a woman's reticule basket—the box appeared quite full of things—I took the trunk on the dickey, the other things were put into the cab—he ordered me to drive to the Spotted Horse, in the Strand—I said I did not know the Spotted Horse, I knew the Spotted' Dog—he said that was all the same—I drove him there, assisted him in taking off the luggage, which was put in front of the bar—it is a booking-office—I saw him pay eight-pence for booking.

MARY ANN HAZLEWOOD . I was barmaid at the Spotted Dog, in the Strand. On Thursday the 7th of April, the prisoner booked a quantity of things there, and gave the name of Stanley—he said nothing more about them—he went away in a very few minutes, came back again about ten or half-past with a female, and went into the coffee-room with her—I cannot say how long they staid—they went away together and took all the things with them—I believe they went in a cab, but I did not see.

THOMAS SAYLES . I was waiter at the Spotted Dog on Thursday, the 7th of April. I remember a man coming there in the morning—the pri
soner is that man—he had a female with him—they came into the tap-room—he had a beef steak in his hand, and asked me to cook it for him—I said I had a very bad fire and could not—he said, "I don't mind waiting, I am from Bristol"—I cooked the steak—they both sat down and ate it—they were very thick in conversation together—all the conversation I noticed was, he made a reply to the female, "That b—ch won't trouble you any more"—I am quite sure I heard the prisoner say that to the woman—I saw him go for a cab—some things were put into the cab and some outside—they were all taken away—I did not see them start—he kept frequently going and outside the door—I suppose he went in and out seven or eight times while the steak was cooking, and while it was being eaten he went out twice—he was in the house about half-an-hour, and went out as much as eight times during that time.
Cross-examined. Q. What day was this? A. Thursday, the 7th of April, at ten o'clock in the morning—I saw the female at Bow-street.
COURT. Q. Did she pass by any name at Bow-street? A. Yes, Mary Good—it was the woman now in custody by that name—(looking at her).

GEORGE BLAND . I drive a cab, No. 430. On Thursday, the 7th of April I saw the prisoner at the Spotted Dog, Strand—I drove him from there down to No. 4, Flower and Dean-street, Spitalfields—he had a bed, a box, and one or two bundles inside the cab—Molly Good was with him—they went into the house.

WILLIAM PARDOE BIDDLE . I am assistant to Mr. Soames, a pawnbro
ker. I saw the prisoner first on Thursday, the 7th of April—he came to my shop first alone, and afterwards accompanied by a woman by the name of Mary Good—I have known her by that name some time—he came into the shop, inquired if we would take in some bed and bedding and a trunk as pledges—we objected to it not knowing any thing of him—he went away and returned with Mrs. Good—I had known bur during the time I had been with Mr. Soames, eleven months—she said in his presence, "It is all right, Mr. Soames, you need not be afraid, it is my husband just come from sea"—in about an hour after he brought a trunk, went away, and returned in about ten minutes with the bed—I went away to dinner, and returned in half
an-hour—he was still there, and the trunk open with the things displayed on the counter—he got 2l. 10s. on them—he said he had just come by rail
way, and wanted to go into the country, which was the reason he wanted to raise money, and that the goods belonged to a passenger who died on his way home from India, and gave him all these things—he returned in about ten minutes with a bundle of women's wearing apparel, and some odd china—there was two mantillas, a white scarf, shawl, a black figured shawl, and some odd cups and saucers—the police have some of the appa
rel and I the rest, which I produce.

STEPHEN LUDLOW . I am special constable of Tunbridge, Kent. On the 16th of April, in consequence of information from a man named Rose, I went to where I found the prisoner, and identified him—I then went into the town to the inspector, communicated with him, and went with Humphreys to where the prisoner was—the inspector brought him away—I found a watch on him and some money, and a woman's jaconet apron—there are spots of blood on it—he was taken into custody by Humphrey—he was dressed in pair of trowsers and a short fustian jacket, as a bricklayer—I did not see him with a had.

GUILTY . Aged 44.—
DEATH .

1706.
MARY GOOD was indicted
for feloniously receiving, harbouring, and maintaining the said
Daniel Good, knowing him to have committed the said murder.
Also for receiving on the 7th of April, 1 piece of silk, value 1s.; 1 shawl, value 2s.; 2 work boxes, value 2s.; the property of
Charles James,
Lord Bishop of London; and 1 pair of trowsers, value 5s.; the goods of
James Stapleton Collingbourn, knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

(Upon which indictments the Learned Attorney-General offered no evi
dence.)
NOT GUILTY .

1707.
RICHARD GAMBLE was indicted
for feloniously receiving, on the 7th of April, 3 gowns, value 3s.; the goods of
Charles James,
Lord Bishop of London; and 2 shirts, value 3s., the goods of
Solomon Penny; knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.—Three other COUNTS, varying the manner of laying the property.
Mr. Attorney-General offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

1708.
ELIZA HEBBERT was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of March, 1 gown, value 6s.; the goods of
John Spragg and another.

JOSEPH NEWMAN PERKINS . I am shopman to Mr. Perkins, a pawn
broker, at Rotherhithe. On the 7th of March, about seven o'clock in the morning, the prisoner pawned a gown with me for 3s. in the name of Mary Pritchard, Adam-street—a person of the name of Pritchard was with her at the time.
Prisoner. The gown was brought to my house by Ann Pritchard, who lived next door to me; she told me she had bought it for 5s. 6d. among other duplicates.

WILLIAM JOSEPH TAYLOR . I am shopman to John Spragg, a pawnbro
ker, at Rotherhithe. On the 7th of March we hung a gown on the door, within the door-post—it was safe between one and two o'clock—in the course of the day Mary Pritchard came and pawned a piece of cotton, and went away—I saw nothing of the prisones.
NOT GUILTY .

1709.
JOHN GOODFELLOW was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of April, 1 brush, value 4s., the goods of
George Bromfield, his master.

EMILY BROMFIELD . I am the wife of George Bromfield, a brush-maker, of 87, Bridge-house-place, Southwark. The prisoner was our porter for about eleven months. On the 15th of April, about a quarter after eight o'clock at night, I was in the warehouse, and in consequence of what Holi
day said to me I sent the prisoner out of the warehouse—he had a coat hanging on a nail in the warehouse—I saw this brush taken from the pocket by Ann Holiday when I had sent him out—I had desired him to leave and not return till Mr. Bromfield came back, but not coming back as soon as I expected, I gave him into custody.

Prisoner. Mr. Bromfield was out of town. Mrs. Bromfield had some words with me on Friday; she did not charge me with taking the brush then, but on Friday night ordered me to come for my wages on Saturday night, which I did; but she would not give them to me; I did not leave till she did; she sent for two policeman to take me out of the premises; she said she discharged me because I took half-an-hour for breakfast in the morning. Witness. I did not say so—up to two months ago we had the greatest confidence in him, but on Good Friday we went out to dinner, and the ser
vant told us he had taken some things out, a quantity of brushes—I men
tioned it to him, he said they had been gone out for orders; I looked at the day-book, and found it was not so—when he came on Saturday my husband had not returned, and I gave him in charge.

Prisoner. I was not out of the warehouse all night. Witness. Yes, I sent him out—he staid out about half-a-minute, just while we took the brush out—he returned in an instant—I did not charge him with it then, but

told the servant to take care of it—I told him to leave the premises, and not return till his master came home—he shut up and left—this was Fri
day—he came to work next morning, but I told the servant not to let him in—he came at night for his wages—I said his master would say what he had to say to him, and settle with him, when he came home—he was excessively impertinent, and I sent for a policeman.

HANNAH HOLIDAY . I am servant to Mr. Bromfield—I held a candle while mistress went round the warehouse on Friday night, about a quarter to nine o'clock—I passed the prisoner's coat, hanging on a nail, and it hit my arm—I spoke to mistress—she told the prisoner to go over to Mrs. White's and see what o'clock it was, and while he was gone I had only time to take this brush out of his coat pocket—I took it down to the kitchen-drawer—mistress told me to keep it—the prisoner came back di
rectly—mistress said, "Shut up the house directly, and get out of my house, and never come near till Saturday night, when your master will be at home"—she did not explain why—he came next morning, and wassent away again—he put on the coat the brush was found in that Friday night—I gave the brush to the policeman on Sunday morning.

Prisoner. That girl is bribed to say what she does; Mrs. Bromfield has bad so many servants; the policeman has got a strap which I was ordered to thrash her with to make her comply with Mrs. Bromfield's request; because I would not do it, she would frequently throw water over her; I said I would not thrash her; I would rather thrash her mistress. Witness. She sent him down to frighten me because I would not take my medicine—she did not order him to strap me on the back—he came with a strap in his hand—he did not say anything—he said he was going to hit me with the strap because I would not take my medicine—I took it, and he did not strap me—master's brother never offered to strap me—it is true that I found this brush in his pocket—I did not put it in, and do not believe that mistress did—the coat hung behind the door—when the door opened the coat was against the wall—I have been in the service going on for four months.

WELLINGTON WEBSTER (police-constable N 81.) I received the pri
soner in charge on Sunday morning, the 17th—Holiday delivered me the brush—when the prisoner was charged with stealing it, he said, "Is that all? I thought it was something more than that "—he told the ser
vant she was bribed to say what she had.

GEORGE BROMFIELD (examined by the Prisoner.) Q. Did you ever suspect me of taking any thing off your premises A. Yes, I have—I did not tell you so, or I should not have caught you—I have suspected you for two months—I missed goods repeatedly from the stock, and you were the only one in the warehouse.

Q. Had not Benjamin Bromfield as much access to the warehouse as I had? A. He was foreman, but he conducted himself in such a curious manner I was obliged to discharge him—when I came home he said he was going to leave the country, and he has gone to live with the prisoner, and he sent back several towels, pillow-cases, and one of the servants gowns, which he said had been taken by mistake.

Prisoner. A man was discharged who spoke for me at Union-ball' Witness. I have discharged Benjamin Bromfield, a boy named Follet, and a man named Beaumont, but he never came, as he had got another place—I returned home on the Friday after the robbery—I was on a journey—I discharged the three men, because I thought I had better have fresh faces

altogether from their running to Union-hall instead of attending to business—I was out of town when the examination took place, and my wife unpro
tected—Benjamin Bromfield, instead of appearing there for me, left her to manage it herself—I thought they might be concerned with him and discharged them—they were valuable men to me, but still I thought it proper, and the prisoner was a valuable servant—I know of no dispute between him and Mrs. Bromfield—I told her to mark the brushes, as we have been missing them—she marked them B, and we found this one corresponding with that—it is now very faint, as it has been handled a good deal—Benjamin Bromfield was my brother—about twelve months ago I was enticed by my father to become his partner, but he became bankrupt—there was property con
cealed, and I sent two officers with the prisoner to take possession of it—since this Benjamin Bromfield comes forward to give this man character—I cannot swear the brush is my make only from the mark which I saw this minute.

WELLINGTON WEBSTER
re-examined. I have had the brush since, it was at Union-hall—there was a mark referred to there, but it is not quite visible—no mark has been put since I have had it when I first had it Mrs. Bromfield pointed out a mark—there was an impression, but I can
not say it was a B.

MRS. BROMFIELD. I think the mark was here—it was a capital B in pencil—on my solemn oath, I did not put the brush into the prisoner's pocket, nor know of its being put there—I was always anxious he should get forward, and had no occasion to find fault with him—Mr. Bromfield raised his wages, and was talking of making him warehouseman if he could write better.

HANNAH HOLIDAY
re-examined. I did not put the brush into his poc
ket, nor did any body, I noticed it in striking against his coat—I had no idea there was a brush there—I whispered about it to mistress, and she sent him out of the warehouse.

JURY. Q. Did the coat hang outside the door or inside? A. Outside—the door opening hid the coat—it was shut when my arm touched it—it leads from the warehouse into the shop—the coat hung on the front shop door—I was in the front shop, and going into the warehouse, when I brushed against it.

MR. BROMFIELD. The front the premises I call the war house—be
yound the warehouse there is a workshop—there is a door from the ware-house into the workshop—it opens into the warehouse—a coat behind that door would be hid when door opened—in opening the door it must have hung before her—the door is very small and narrow, and the coat would with large pockets, which he put on when he went away—a person passing from one room to the other must touch the coat to pull the door open—there is no lock nor latch to it—I believe there is a little bit of wood to take hold of.

Prisoner. My coat did hang no the door at all, but on a post at the side, about half-a-yard from the door when it is open. Witness. There is a rack behind the door, with poles to put brooms on, and large shelves separated by posts.
Prisoner. What was it? I did not go out Good Friday with my coat on. Witness. Oh, John! You went out at the front door, with your
coat on, about four o'clock—I do not know where you were going—you had a fustian jacket on—I call that a coat.

Prisoner. I hope the Jury will consider my character; she has thought proper to charge me with this because I took half-an-hour to my break fast and tea; this is the second plot laid against me; she sent into the work shop, and ordered the apprentice to weigh some hair, which he did; she said, "Take it to Cann's, in Chiswell-strcet, and if he buys it come and tell me, I will come and send a policeman, and give him in charge;" Cann is a respectable oil-merchant.

MRS. BROMFIELD. I ordered some hair to be weighed, and sent the prisoner with it, by my husband's direction, as Cann had offered my hus
band some bristles—I have heard people say he was not a bristle-mer
chant, that he bought them from men who stole them; and before my hus
band should buy bristles, fearing they might be bought improperly, I sent to sell these, to try him.

Q. You sent your servant to test his honesty, to see if he would pur
chase, in an indirect manner? A. Yes, before my husband should pur
chase of him—this was three or four months ago—the bristles were not such as a merchant sold, but mixed, such as we often lose—I told the prisoner my object—I never quarrelled with the prisoner, nor did my husband.

GEORGE WEBB BROMFIELD . I am the prosecutor's father. The pri
soner was with me five years, till my son decoyed him away from my service his own—it was a plan between my son and his wife—they are excellent to good sort of people in that business, to take my men away, and my busi
ness, &c.—the prisoner bore an excellent character—I have another son—the prosecutor decoyed him away, and he has found it out—he was dis
charged as well as the boy, and it is coming round again to fair play—I believe the brush was put into the prisoner's pocket.
NOT GUILTY .

1710.
JOHN EYLES was indicted
for stealing, on the 31st of March, 13 metal cocks, value 18s., the goods of
Stephen Green, his master.

ROBERT HUNTM . I am clerk to Stephen Green, a manufacturer of stone-ware, at Lambeth—he has between sixty and seventy men in hit employ. The prisoner was one, and had been so five years, at different times—in consequence of property being missed, I was directed to watch the men who go to breakfast at eight o'clock, and return at half-past eight—the prisoner went at half-past eight, and came back at nine, that the premises might never be left—he would have the charge of the yard while the men went to breakfast—his business during that time was to try the bottles, to see if they were sound—I placed myself behind a wall with a hole in it, which commanded a view of the inner store-room, where we keep brass taps used for filtering machines—I went out of the counting-house at five minutes to eight, as if I was going to breakfast, and returned by a back
way, to the place in the wall—in about a quarter of an hour I saw the prisoner, through the window of the counting-house, enter the first count
ing-house, very cautiously—he then entered the second counting-house—I then got up to the hole in the wall, and saw him enter the store-room—he then procured something to stand on, to reach the brass cocks, which were

in a cupboard over the door of the store-room—he first took down a quan
tity of taps from a broken parcel, placed them on his left arm, and then reached down a sound parcel, containing six taps—he closed the door with his right hand, removed what he stood on, and proceeded cautiously through the counting-house, with them on his arm—I then went from where I was, to the counting-house—be did not see me—when he got through the outer counting-house I opened the counting-house door which leads into the factory, and, with the noise of the door opening, he turned round to see who it was—I said nothing to him, nor he to me, but I took the taps from him, in a basket—I said, "This is quite sufficient, Eyles"—he then went down the counting-house stairs, without saying any thing—I went to speak to the foreman, and while doing so, he took his hat, walked out of the yard, and went out of the premises—it was not the time to leave, as the men had not returned—he never came back—I never saw him again till he was in custody, about a fortnight or three weeks after
find him before—these are the thirteen taps which I took from the basket in his hand, which belongs to master—they are of two different makers, seven made by Walker, marked, "No. 2" and six by Stevens, marked, "No. 267."

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you mark them before you gave them to the policeman? A. I did, I have my initials on them—I knew where the prisoner lived—I knew he was married—I know he had one child in the prosecutor's employment—I do not know how many others he has—I went in search of him to York-street, Blackfriars-road, where a relation of his lives—I thought he might sleep there, as he did not go home—I did not tell him he was discharged, and not to come again, nothing of the kind.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Had he any business in your store-room? A. None at all, he had no business to leave the yard—he had no right to meddle with these goods without a special order.

JOSEPH BAKER . I am the prosecutor's foreman. On the morning of the 31st of March, the prisoner had charge to the yard from eight o'clock to half-past—his duty was not to leave the yard at all—he had no business in the counting-house or store-room—from that day I went in search of him till the 25th of April—I could not find him at his house—I was out every night after him—I at last found him at a lodging be had taken in Queen's-court, near Park-street—he was not dressed as usual—he had a round frock on, like a coal heaver.

Cross-examined. Q. How near did you find him to your master's premises? A. Within five minutes' walk—I found him with his wife there—he has four or five children—I never had any quarrel with him—the taps were used for stone filterers—it has not been his duty to put them on for twelve months past.

WILLIAM BUTT . I am employed in the factory, it is my business to check the number of metal cocks, to see if any are missing, they are kept in the inner store-room, the prisoner had no right to meddle with them at all; there had been some lost before, and there were new regulations made. On the 31st of March there was nineteen of No. 2 Walker's—I ascertained the quantity at half-past six o'clock the same morning, and there was 146 of Stevens', No. 267—a little before nine the same morn
ing when I came from breakfast I examined the stock again, and missed
seven of Walker's and six of Stevens'—the cocks produced I had in my hand at half-past six—they are the property of my master.
CHARLES BURGESS GOFF . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner in charge—I had been hunting for him at various places, from the 31st of March to the 25th of April.

Cross-examined. Q. You charged him with stealing thirteen taps? A. Yes, he said, "I stole no taps"—I had looked for him in the neigh
bourhood of the factory, and of his residence, and found him within a few minutes' walk of the prosecutor's—he had left his old lodging.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 45.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined One Year.

1711.
WILLIAM KINGTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of April, at Camberwell, 3 pairs of trowsers, value 3l.; 5 waistcoats, value 1l. 5s.; 2 coats, value 4l.; 1 brooch, value 2l.; 2 hair-pins, value 10s.; and 1 bracelet, value 10s.; the goods of
Edmund Philips, in his dwell
ing-house; and that he bad been previously convicted of felony.

DANIEL NAISH . I am a carpenter. On the 16th of April, about twelve o'clock in the day, I saw the prisoner at Rose-villa, Well-street, Camberwell—he opened the front-gate, walked up the gravel-walk, went round into the back-yard, and shut the gate after him—I could not see him after that—he went round the end of the house—I waited about ten minutes, and then rung at the bell of the front-gate—Mrs. Philips opened the front-door—I told her what I had seen—I was taking a pint of beer to the house—she took the beer, and I went into the kitchen with her—I went out, and called Mr. Burrows to help me search the house—we searched the out-house, and bottom part of the house, and found nobody-Mrs. Philips and Mr. Burrows went up stairs together to look, and gave an alarm—Mr. Burrows and I and one Smith, went up stairs, and saw the prisoner in a bed-room, standing between the bed and the window—it was a quarter of an hour after I had seen him at the back-door—Mr. Philips was on the landing—we took the prisoner, and gave him into custody to Sergeant Dinn.

ELIZA PHILIPS . Naish gave me information—I went up stairs, looked under the bed, and saw a man there—I called Mr. Naish up to take him, and when I did so, he got up from under the bed—he was taken—I missed some hair-pins, a brooch, and a small bracelet, from the pincushion of the toilet-table—I saw the sergeant take a bundle from under the bed which the prisoner had been under—it contained some clothes of Mr. Philipi's, which were kept in the drawers of the same bed-room—I had seen them there in the morning—I have seen the trinkets since in possession of Dinn—these now produced are them.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You bad a servant in your em
ployment at this time? A. Yes, I am quite sure no else one was concerned in this matter—the servant left in consequence of illness—I do not know the value of the trinkets, they were given to me.

EDMUND PHILIPS . I came home when the prisoner was on the road to the station—I went and met Dinn, and saw this brooch, two hair-pins, and a bracelet, taken from the prisoner's pocket—after leaving him at the sta
tion, Dinn went to my house with me—on going up stairs, I found a bundle under the bed, containing the clothes now produced, tied in a handker
chief that did not belong to me—I had seen them that morning, an hour or two before.

Cross-examined. Q. Was there anybody else in your house who might have put them under the bed? A. No, we occasionally hired a person to do work for us, being without a servant—nobody was there but the girl—we have parted with her on account of illness—she was not a regular servant, but merely came for a few days—we did not know her before, but knew her family—my house is in the parish of Camberwell—I believe it is St. Giles's—I know it is in Camberwell parish—I have seen "Camberwell" on the vestry papers—I should think the clothes are worth 8l.—there is a great-coat, a dress-coat, and five waistcoats.

THOMAS BARNABAS DINN . I am a police-sergeant. I took the pri
soner in charge, and found these trinkets on him—I saw him throw a brooch and some hair-pins on the ground—I took one from his band, and the rest off the ground—I went with Mr. Philips to the house, and found a bundle under the bed.

SAMUEL WRIGHT . I am a policeman. I produced a certificate of the pri
soner's former conviction—(read)—I was present when he pleaded guilty, and know him to be the person.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1712.
WILLIAM HARISS was indicted
for feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Jemima Jane Nicholls, on the 25th of April, at Camberwell, and stealing therein 6 rings, value 15s.; 5 brooches, value 15s.; 3 seals, value 10s.; 1 pair of ear-rings, value 5s.; 2 pencil-value cases, value 12s.; 4 spoons, value 14s.; 1 knife, value 2s.; 1 eye-glass, 4s.; 1 neck chain, value 2s.; 1 pair of bracelets, value 3s.; 1 cross, value 1s.; 1 snap, value 2s.; 1 scent-bottle, value 1s.; 1 pair of studs, value 1s.; 1 necklace, value 1s.; 2 sovereigns, 1 shilling, 1 sixpence, 2 groats, and 1 silver coin, called a "threepence," the property of the said Jemima Jane Nicholls,

JEMIMA JANE NICHOLLS . I live in Denmark-road, in the parish of Camberwell. On the 25th of April, between eleven and twelve o'clock at noon, I left my house with my son who lives with me—I left the front door double locked, and the gate, the parlour door, and the door at the end of the passage, locked, but the outer door, which goes into the garden, was open, and ajar—there is a garden and a field in the rear of the house, and a road that runs parallel with our road and the cross-road leading to it—I received information, and returned to my house about five o'clock, I found the gate still locked, the street-door on the single lock, the back-parlour door open, and also the door leading to the kitchen, which I had left locked—on going up stairs, I found the drawer of the looking-glass, which I had locked, forced open—a desk in the parlour was broken open, and the things scattered about—I missed some coins from the desk, and from the looking-glass drawer a pair of bracelets, six rings, four brooches, and other articles, the whole worth between 5l. and 6l.—I lost a table and tea-spoon.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. Are you a widow? A. Yes, I rent the house—I am certain my son locked the door—I was standing at the gate at the time, and asked him particularly if he had double locked it—the gate is two or three yards from the door, but I stood at the door—I
saw him turn the handle of the lock—I should have known it was done if I had not inquired—I have not the least doubt of it.

GEORGE MERRINGTON . I am a carpenter, and live in Denmark-street. The back of my house faces the front of the prosecutrix's—about noon, on the 25th of April, I saw the prisoner walking backwards and for
wards some time before the prosecutrix's house—I saw him try the gate several times, and then he got over the gate, and opened the front door—I did not see any key, because he stood in front of the keyhole, but he ap
peared to be putting something to it—I did not see any thing in his hand—his hands were in front of him, as if he was opening it with a key—I saw him open the door—he then went in and shut it, I then went round to the front of the house—I found Goddard standing in the road—I told him to remain there while I went for a policeman—when I returned I found the prisoner in the hands of a policeman.

Cross-examined. Q. What was you doing at this time? A. Look
ing out of the window—I have been ill some time, and was not at work—my house is about 100 yards from the prosecutrix's—there is a meadow, and a garden between them—our garden is about 130 feet from the road—I could identify a person at that distance—I will not swear it is within a quarter of a mile—he was at the door about a minute.
MR. LILLY. Q. When you saw him in custody, were you certain he was the person you had seen in front of the house? A. Yes.

JOHN DONALD GODDARD . I am a druggist, and live at No. 68, Hatton-garden. About half-past one o'clock, on the 25th of April, I was in Denmark-road, Camberwell, and was spoken to at the front of the prose
cutrix's house—from what was said to me I went round to the back of the house, and went to the side of the house to get to the back, along a sort of passage—when I got to the back I saw the prisoner in the garden, and asked him if be belonged to the house—he said he did—I told him some
body was in front, and he had better go and answer the door—he went in, and I went to the front again, supposing from his appearance he belonged to the house—when I got in the front I saw the back of the prisoner, walk
ing about 100 yards off in the high road—I suppose he had got over the gardens, but could not see—he could not have come up the passage—I ran after him, and on my beginning to run he looked round, and ran too—I overtook him with considerable difficulty—I ran some distance—I brought him back opposite the house, and held him till a policeman came—he was taken to the station—I am able to swear to him from what I saw of him.

Cross-examined. Q. I think you saw him come into the garden. A. Yes—he did not appear to have any thing about him—I was at the back of the garden, in a field, about as far from him as I am from you—I did not see him go into the house—I shouted out—he was walking along lei
surely when I first saw him—I am certain of him by his general appear
ance—I recollect his features.

THOMAS MATTHEWS . I am a policeman. On the 25th of April the prisoner was given into my custody by Goddard—I observed two silver spoons in his right-hand breeches pocket—I attempted to search him, and took them from his pocket, when he refused to be searched any further—I took him to the station—he was searched there, and I found on him two sovereigns, five brooches, one table-spoon, two tea-spoons, and one salt
spoon, six gold rings, three seals, one pair of ear-rings, a gold and a silver pencil-case, a pearl-handled knife, two bracelets, an eye-glass, a cross, a
necklace, a scent-bottle, and other articles, with three picklock-keys—I did not try the keys to the door.
Cross-examined. Q. The spoons protruded from his pocket? A. Yes, I could see them.

MRS. NICHOLLS re-examined. The articles produced are all mine.
GUILTY. Aged 19.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutrix, on ac
count of his youth. —
Transported for Ten Years.

1713.
CATHERINE DONOVAN was indicted
for feloniously as
saulting
Catherine Mahoney, on the 26th of April, and cutting and wound
ing her in and upon the left side of the head, with intent to do her some grievous bodily harm.

CATHERINE MAHONEY . I am single, and lodge at No. 6, Redcross-court, Borough—the prisoner's husband rents the house, and is my land
lord. On the night of the 26th of April he applied to my mother for a week's rent—she could not pay it—he went down to his room, and I heard the prisoner using very low language, and calling the old woman hard names—I said my mother did not look more like the names she called her than her mother did, and then she called me the names myself—I had a bit of potato in my hand eating, and I flung it at her—then she took the chopper from the side of her kitchen fire-place in her kitchen (I must go through the kitchen to get to my room) she said, the first one that came down the stairs that night she would chop their b——head off—my mother came and locked the door—about half-an-hour after I went down for some water, and saw her with the chopper in her hand—I said, "I think you are going to do what you said"—she said, "Yes, I intend to do it"—I said, "I will see whether my head will be chopped off or not," and then she gave me a violent blow on the forehead—I flinched back from it, and received it on the top of my head, and did not receive the violent blow she was going to give me, or it would have been straight down my face—it came lighter on me through my falling back—I fell to avoid the blow—I called my mother down, and said, "I am murdered by the chopper"—she came to my assistance, and I was taken to the hospital.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You were quite yourself? A. Yes—I did not use any bad language to her, nor give her any provocation—my mother had some words with her, but I did not interfere—I said, "Mrs. Donovan, you called my mother an old b—-, but she is no more one than you are"—I did not say, "There you are sitting there, a w—to your own brother"—on my oath she did not say, if I called her a w—to her own brother again, she would chop my head—I did not say I would prove what I had said—that I swear—she had a child on her lap when I threw the hot potato—I do not know where it hit her—I will swear it did not hit her in the face—I threw it into her lap—I threw it as hard as I could—it did not hit the child—it came into her lap—I was four stairs off when I threw it—I do not know that she had her cap torn off, and her hair pulled about—I left her and my mother together—I swear the child was not knocked down before I went to the hospital—three years ago last August I had a few words with a neighbour, and was sent to prison because I could not pay 40s.—I did not nearly knock a young woman's eye out with a brick-bat—I was sent to Kingston gaol for it, and was there twenty-one days—I was never in prison in my life before—I was never in Brixton
gaol in my life—they never said they wanted their room—we are out of the place now—we went last week.

ALLEN WILLIAMS . I am assistant to Charles Key, surgeon of Guy's Hospital. I saw the prosecutrix on the 26th—she had a wound on the left side of her head, it was not serious at all—she was quite sensible—it was about an inch and a half long, and a quarter of an inch deep, quite to the bone—the integuments of the skin were cut through to that extent—I have seen the chopper—a similar wound might be produced by just the sharp part of it.

Cross-examined. Q. Was the wound serious? A. No, a little dress
ing soon cured it—if very much force was used, this weapon would inflict a very serious wound.

MARY MOREEN . I am the wife of Timothy Moreen, and live in the house. I was there the night this happened, and heard Mrs. Donovan and Mahoney's mother having words—Catherine Mahoney came down stairs, and the prisoner asked her husband if he had been up—he said, "Yes, and she says she will pay me the rent to-morrow night"—the prosecutrix said the prisoner was a w—to her own brother, and she could prove it, she took the child in her arms, and took the chopper, and said, "If you call me that again, I will hit you with this"—the prosecutrix said, "I can prove it"—the husband got up to hit her—I took him by the hand, and said, "Have sense, man, and don't touch her"—she then threw the potato in the prisoner's face—she went up stairs, and came down after
wards, and said, "Now I will know whether I am to be hit with the chopper or no," and she hit her, and Mrs. Mahoney came down and took her by the hair of her head—the prisoner's husband was beating the three women, with the child under their feet—the prisoner struck two blows with the chopper—the first took effect in the face—she had a child in her arms—she did not strike her first on the arm—if it had not been for the expressions of the prosecutrix, it would not have happened—nobody could stand them—I believe she struck twice with the chopper—I know she struck once—I believe this is the chopper—it was left in the room—the policeman came for it, and got it.

Cross-examined. Q. You picked the child off the ground? A. Yes—I saw the prosecutrix strike the prisoner with the potato—after that old Mrs. Mahoney caught hold of the prisoner by the hair, and tore her cap—that was after the chopper was used.

ROBERT IRESON (police-constable M 113.) I was called to the house between eight and nine o'clock—I noticed a few spots of blood on the wall and a spot or two outside the house—I took the prisoner's husband into custody—the prisoner followed, and came into the station and said, "It was not my husband who did it, it was me struck the party with the chop
per"—I got the chopper afterwards from the house.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY of an Assault only. Aged 26.—
Confined Four Months.

1714.
LOTH AIR SOHLE was indicted
for feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Richard Thomas, on the 3rd of May, at Camberwell, and stealing therein, 1 chronometer, value 30l.; 7 forks, va
lue 7s.; 1 razor, value 6d.; and 1 pair of gloves, value 6d.; his property;to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 37.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1715.
JOHN SIMMONS was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of April, a double-branch gas-fitting, value 2l. the goods of
Frederick West.

FREDERICK WEST . I am a baker, and live in Tooley-street, and have another shop in Suffolk-street. On the 1st of April, I left the shop in Suffolk-street locked up—I went there again on the 8th of April, found the door open, and missed the gas-fittings, a drinking-glass, a gas-branch, a brass-cock, and other articles—I afterwards saw the branch at Mr. Fisk's shop, in New Cut, and knew it again—I do not know the prisoner.

HENRY COE . I am a policeman. I have a double gas-branch, which I got at Fisk's shop on the 9th of April—I compared it with the prosecutor's shop where it had been fixed, and it corresponded with the screw-holes and every thing.
HENRY FISK . I am a cabinet-maker, and live at Nos. 15 and 16, New Cut, Lambeth. I bought this gas-branch of Davis, who keeps a shop in Friar-street.
MOSS DAVIS , being called, did not appear.

JOHN CROWTHER . At the latter end of last year I made this branch for Mr. West.
NOT GUILTY .

1716.
JOHN PEARL was indicted
for feloniously breaking and enter
ing the warehouse of
Robert Goulding, on the 12th of April, at St. John, Southwark, and stealing therein, 4 bushels of beans, value 16s., his pro
perty.

WILLIAM NETTLETON . I am clerk to Robert Goulding, a corn-merchant and warehouseman, carrying on business in Potter's Fields, St. John's, Southwark—I have lived with him thirty years—there is nobody but him in the firm—it is carried on as Robert Goulding and Son, but there is no
body but him in it. On the evening of the 12th of April, about seven o'clock, I was leaving the counting-house, and went round to the different doors to see that they were fast—on coming to the back-door of the warehouse, "B No. 1," I found the top part of the door open—I went up to the door and saw two men, each filling a bushel bag with beans—there was a balk of beans at the other end of the warehouse—I asked what they did there, and how they came there—one of them, not the prisoner, escaped almost immediately, so that I could not ascertain who he was—the prisoner came towards me and said it was all right—I said, "No, it is not all right," and asked what business they had there, and how they came in—he said it was all right, and endeavoured to make his escape—I was outside the door—the door was between us—I pushed him back and kept calling for the police—he attempted to come out at the top of the door—it is a divided door—the other man went to the other end of the warehouse, and I suppose must have dropped from the first-floor window—there was no other means of his get
ting away—before the policeman came the prisoner had made his escape into the other warehouse, and we went in search of him—I expect he knew the warehouse, and had been there before—the sack containing the beans was just outside the door where I saw him, ready to be carried away, besides the two sacks they were filling—the beans in the sack and bags corresponded in quality with those in the bulk—after securing the prisoner we went over the warehouse, and the following morning, about nine o'clock, I examined the back window and found one iron bar of the window standing in its proper position, but it was loose—anybody without could remove it to get in—the back-door of the warehouse was fastened from within—you could

not get in at the back of the premises except by the window—the front part of the warehouse was fastened with a common lock, and the Queen's lock also—they were quite undisturbed—the back-window is about two yards from the ground—any body could get through the window and unfasten the back-door within—a man could not get out of the up stairs warehouse without dropping from the window, unless he had a ladder, and that was found—he could not get out at the lower window, because I stood there.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. You say there is nobody in the concern but Robert Goulding? A. Yes—the beans belong to Mr. Millis Coventry, a corn-factor—the warehouse is a place for the safe keeping of goods—the back-door is divided in the centre—I found the upper part open—it is, perhaps, three yards high from top to bottom—there is no thoroughfare at the back of the premises—it is an entrance to our yard—I made no examination of the upper window that evening particu
larly—I do not know what had occurred to it since.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Were the beans entrusted to your master for safe keeping? A. Yes—he is accountable for them—Mr. Coventry pays ware house room to my master for them.

JOHN FERNS . I am in the service of Mr. Goulding—I was on the premises, in the warehouse B No. 1—on the 12th of April, about four o'clock in the afternoon, I closed the warehouse—the front-door was se
cured by a lock and latch, and the Queen's lock too—I saw the back
door secured inside—there was no fastening to the front—I came out at the front-door, and saw both the locks made fast—I did not examine the window bars.

WILLIAM SMITH . I am a policeman. I received information from Nettleton, went up to the second-floor, and saw the prisoner on the tiles of the lower warehouse endeavouring to escape—I took possession of the sack of beans and two bags—I went down stairs, round to the back premises, and met my brother constable, who got a ladder to get on to the roof, but received information that the prisoner had dropped from the wall again into an enclosed building—we went there, and found him lying on the bulk of corn—I examined the building that night—the bars of the back window seemed correct, but I did not take hold of them to try them—I tried them at nine o'clock the following morning, and found a bar unfastened—the nails bad been drawn,-and the bar removed, and put back in its place again—I bad not observed that the night before—I received the prisoner in charge—I had seen him in Tooley-street shortly before.

THOMAS TATE . I am a policeman. I went round the warehouse B No. 1, and found my brother constable there—I saw the back-window that night, but did not notice any thing the matter with it—I did not examine it particularly—I saw the prisoner endeavouring to escape, and afterwards secured him.

WILLIAMNETTLETON re-examined. Mr. Goulding keeps his own goods at the warehouse for sale as well as other people's—the beans were not in bond, but there was wheat in the same warehouse—they were in bond when first put there—Mr. Coventry might bring people there to look at them, but they generally sell them by sample at the market.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. Could you have got them out without the party who puts the Queen's lock on coming? A. I could not have taken off the Queen's lock—it is taken off at eight o'clock in the morning, and put on at four o'clock in the afternoon.

GUILTY . Aged 29.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1717.
LUCY COLLARD was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of March, 1 shirt, value 10s.; 1 sheet, value 9s.; and 2 handkerchiefs, value 5s.; the goods of
William Hayden, her master.

WILLIAM HAYDEN . I am a haberdasher—the prisoner was my servant of all-work, and had 8l. a year. On Sunday, the 24th of April I missed some things, which made me look to see if any thing else was gone, and I missed a sheet—I told her I would not be satisfied till I had got the sheet—in consequence of what she said to me I found the shirt, sheet, and two handkerchiefs at Mr. Turner's, a pawnbroker, in Walworth-road—I went there in consequence of seeing the duplicate in her hand—she said she had pawned the sheet—she was not willing for me to get it out, she wished to get it out herself—I said, "You have no money to get it out"—she said she would pawn some of her own things to get it.

Q. How came you to know she had the duplicate? A. We said no
thing about the sheet till Monday morning—I then pressed her to tell me where it was—she said she knew nothing about it—I said nobody had ac
cess to it but herself—then she said she had pawned it, and produced the duplicate—she said there was only the sheet and her own shawl—I went to Turner's, and found the articles—I had seen the shirt safe about a fort
before—the handkerchiefs were in the back-warehouse—I knew the papers they were in were there, but I did not look into them—the police
man found a pair of gloves, which I kept in the same chest of drawers up stairs with the shirt—the drawer was found broken open on the Sunday night—I had seen it safe that afternoon—I always kept it locked—I do not think I had opened it that day—I gave her into custody on the 25th of April.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How long had she been in your service? A. Since the 21st of February—she came as a single woman, I have since found she is married—she told me after a long time that she had pawned the sheet and produced the duplicate, and said she had pawned a shawl of her own at the same time, but that did not prove true—I am a widower—my family consists of a servant and four children—the prisoner did not say she had pledged the things for the purpose of send
ing money down to her son at Bristol—I let her have a sovereign on the 15th of March, and afterwards 5s. on the 20th, to send her son—I saw Turner's name on the duplicate—I think I can swear to the handkerchiefs when I see them—the prisoner said she had brought them from Bristol with her after we found them—she did not deny the shirt and sheet being mine.

CHRISTOPHER THOMAS GREAVES . I am apprentice to Turner, a pawn
broker. I have a shirt, sheet, and two silk handkerchiefs—I wrote the duplicate produced for it on the 5th of March, for 8s.—they were pledged by the woman in the name of Ann Hemmings—I cannot speak to the prisoner.

MR. HAYDEN re-examined. This shirt, sheet, and handkerchiefs I can swear to—the shirt has my name on it—I know the handkerchiefs, in consequence of their being in a damp place they got spotted, and I altered the price of them all, and put a fresh mark on them—the mark is not here—I produce one of the same quality with the same sort of spots on it—I also know the gloves.

Cross-examined. Q. Except the spots there is nothing uncommon about them? A. They are the same kind of handkerchief—after we missed the sheet she told my daughter she had pawned it—she did not say my daugh
ter had authorised her to do so—I had said before that that I would find out where it was.

JOHN LLOYD . I am a policeman. I was called to the house, went up stairs for the prisoner, and told her the prosecutor suspected she had robbed him—she produced the duplicate—I asked if she objected to my searching her boxes—she said, "No," and gave me two keys—I found nothing in her boxes—I took her to the station—she was searched there, and this pair of gloves found on her—she said she picked them up in the room.
Cross-examined. Q. She told you, did not she, that she pawned the things intending to get them again? A. Yes.

GUILTY. Aged 38.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Nine Months.

1718.
WILLIAM BROMELL and
JOHN PETTY were indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of April, 1 jacket, value 15s.; 1 cap, valued.; the goods of
John Edward Cox: 1 pair of trowsers, value 10s.; 1 shirt, value 2s.; and 1 pair of mittens, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
Thomas Luxmore Wilson: and I jacket, value 15s.; 1 handkerchief, value 5s.; and 2 shirts, value 4s.; the goods of
Philip Lybbe Powys ; and
ELIZA
BETH WARREN and
ELLEN LOGDEN
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

THOMAS FULLER . I am in the service of Mr. Searl, of Stangate-street, Lambeth. The members of the Oxford University Aquatic Club have a room on our premises—it is my duty to superintend the room which the gentlemen use to dress in, when they go out in the boats—they keep their clothing and things in lockers all round the room—on Monday, the 4th of April, at half-past nine o'clock, I locked the place up all safe—I returned on Tuesday morning about ten minutes to six, and found the gate open, also a small counting-house, where other gentlemen dress, and saw some of the clothes lying about, some of which belonged to the Club, and had been brought down to that room—I went up to the Oxford room, and found the door wide open—it had been opened with the key which I always leave there, in case the gentlemen should come while I am away—it is twelve o'clock sometimes before they come home—on the morning of the 4th I missed several articles belonging to the gentlemen—I saw some things afterwards produced by the policeman.

CHARLOTTE AUSTIN . I am the wife of Charles Austin, of Whiting-street, Lambeth. I know the prisoner Warren—she came to lodge with me on the 3rd of March, and left on the 5th of April—on the morning of the 5th of April, between ten and eleven o'clock, I went into her room to insist on her leaving it, as she was so noisy, and had so many fol
lowers, and I said I would not leave the room till she was gone—she left the room, and wished me to wait a few minutes till she returned—the prisoner Logden was in the room at the time—she did not lodge with her to my knowledge—Warren left the room to return in ten minutes, as she said, if I would wait, and Logden was to wait till she returned—she did not say what she was to return for, but said she would come back in ten minutes—finding she did not come back, I suspected something! and turned down the bed to see if the bed clothes were all right, and found in the bed twelve gentlemen's coats or jackets, one pair of trowsers, and eleven gentlemen's rowing shirts, tied up in a bundle—Logden was there—there was also a blue silk handkerchief, and a gentleman's cap, and in the drawer I found two drinking horns—there was a pair, of mittens also

—I called up one of my lodgers, Maria Parker, and in consequence of what passed between us, I sent her for a policeman, who came, and I delivered the articles to him—Logden wished me to take some of the things in the room as security for the rent, and let Warren stop till Thursday, till her week was up—I said no, I should take ill the things—the bedstead folds up, and the things were turned up in the bed—I brought them into my own room, and sent for a policeman—Warren did not return—I saw no more of her till she was at Union-hall—Logden did not lodge with me—I do not know how long she had been in the room—nobody could see the things without turning the bed down—she might not know they were there.

MARIA PARKER . I am single, and live at Austin's house. On the 5th of April, between three and four o'clock in the morning, before daybreak, I heard a knocking at the street-door—I knew Warren had got a key—Logden was stopping with her, I know, because I have seen her there—she was at home that night, because I heard her there—I did not see her—I could be positive it was her—I heard somebody in the room, and I bad' seen her on the stairs with Warren frequently—I cannot say she ever slept there—I saw her come down stairs next morning after ten, and spoke to her—after I heard the knocking at the door, I heard somebody get over the wall of the yard, and then heard somebody open the street-door within, and let somebody in—I could hear the footsteps of more than one person come in—I heard them go up stairs—I lodge in the parlour—Warren had the front room, over the parlour—I heard them walking about over my head—shortly after ten in the morning I saw the two male prisoners there—they came down stairs by themselves, and went out—I had never seen them before—the females were not with them—the shortest prisoner said, "Good morning"—I said, "Good morning"—they each bad a bundle, or ft coat, or jacket over their arm—my landlady called me up stairs about twenty minutes after that—I went up, and Logden was there—Mrs. Austin went to turn down the bed to see if the bed-clothes were right, and found these things there—I saw them found—next day we found a bag contain
ing some skeleton-keys, in a drawer, which the constable has—there was all sorts of keys.

COURT. Q. You saw the men at ten o'clock, what time is the house open in the raoriing? A. Generally about seven—many persons might have come in before ten—I did not see who came in at four in the morn
ing—I did not hear any voices—I heard them walking about—the male prisoners could not have come from any room but Warren's, as the other. room was locked up—there was a lodger in the room adjoining Warren's, hot she was in my room at the time, and her door was locked—I do not know whether the people went away that came at four—Warren has visitors, and is, I believe, in an unhappy course of life—I was never dis
turbed before—that is the reason which drew my attention to it—the wall the person got over joins the door at the entrance of the house, and goes to the back part of the house—it was two persons came in at least by the foot-steps—I only heard one person go out after four the morning, and before ten, that was a man who occupies the back
room—he is not here—he went out about nine.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You do not mean to say you kept awake all night? A. No—I did not go to sleep till my clock struck four, and I awoke again about six—I am certain nobody went out

from six to nine—the male lodger goes out to work at nine o'clock in the morning—I believe he is a quill-maker—my name is Maria Parker—that is the name I go by—I get my living many ways—I told Mrs. Austin what I had heard, which made her order them to leave.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You cannot tell how many people might have access to the room? A. They have a great many acquaintances I believe—the street-door is left for anybody to come in and out who has got a key—it is a street-doorkey, and not a latch-key—I have opened the door myself at times to persons who come—I slept till six o'clock—I generally get up at seven—I get out and open the shutters sometimes before I get up.

CHARLES STEWART . I am a policeman. On the 5th of April I went to No. 9, Whiting-street, between ten and eleven o'clock in the morning, and received some articles from Mrs. Austin, which I produce—I inquired if there was anybody in the room—I went up, and found Petty and Logden in the same room as the bedstead was—it was about ten o'clock in the morning—whether it was the front or back-room I cannot say, as it is a curiously-constructed house—Mrs. Parker and Mrs. Austin stood in the passage—when I went into the room I told the prisoners they must go with me to the station—they said nothing—I searched them, and found nothing—I searched the room again next day, and found several articles belonging to the club.

MRS. AUSTIN re-examined. These are what I found in the bed—I took them into my room, and the policeman took them out of my room—he took Petty and Logden in the room Warren lodged in—I removed the articles into the room I occupied myself at the back of the house built over the yard—I gave them to him in my room, not in Warren's.

CHARLES BURGESS GOFF . I am a policeman. I took Warren into custody on the 19th of April, in High-street, Borough—I told her it was for receiving twelve jackets and other articles, stolen from Mr. Searle's, and found in her room—she said, "I know nothing about it; if they are found there, somebody must have put them there."

RICHARD SIMMONS . I am a painter, and know the prisoner Bromell; he is a waterman, and has been in the habit of going out with the Oxford Club at times, when they were short-handed. On the 4th of April, about four o'clock in the afternoon, I saw him and Petty pass the front of Mr. Searle's premises—they only passed as I went out, walking together—I cannot say they were in company, but walking by the side of each other.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Is Mr. Searle's house in the open street? A. No—there is a thoroughfare where they passed, it is Bishop's-walk—anybody might pass there—they walked along as any
body else might—there was nothing remarkable—it is a very usual place for watermen to pass.

JAMES BROOK . I am a policeman. I took Bromell into custody, on the 5th of April, in the Waterloo-road—I told him I wanted him for a rob
bery at Mr. Lankester's—I searched him, and found this cap on his head—I produce a bunch of skeleton keys, which I received from sergeant Jones at the station—he is not here.
MRS. AUSTIN re-examined. These are the keys I gave to the sergeant—there are sixteen and a small crow-bar—I am certain they are the same, I particularly noticed them.

JOHN EDWARD COX . I am a member of the Oxford University Aqua
tic Club, and live at Hyde Park-gate; I am a member of the University. I know this to be my cap, and this jacket is mine, and a comb in the pocket—I lost a comb exactly like it—I had left it in my locker—I went to Searle's room on the Wednesday, and saw a great many of the lockers broken open—the lids were torn up—I did not notice them particularly—I think there were marks of some instrument used to prize them open.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How do you know the cap? A. By the general wear of it—I have no initials on it, but I once cut the strap shorter on one side than the other, that I might fasten it under my chin—it is not a very common kind of cap—I think mine and my brother's are the only ones in the club—I wore it on the 4th of April—I will not swear to the cut—I have no doubt of the cap, I think I should know it among a thousand that had been worn.

THOMAS LUXMORE WILSON . I am a solicitor, and live in Bedford
row. I am not a member of the club—I keep things at Mr. Searle's, in a room under the Oxford room—these trowsers are mine, and this jacket I have worn five years—it has my name in it, written by myself, and I know the mittens and blue striped Guernsey frock.

PHILIP LYBBE POWIS . I am a member of Baliol College, Oxford, and live at Furnival's Inn; I am a member of the club. These two Guernsey frocks are mine, and this jacket I know by the particular sort of lining in the sleeves—I lost a blue handkerchief like this, but cannot speak positively to it—I believe it is mine—one of the frocks has my name in my own handwriting.

CHARLES STEWART
re-examined. I took Petty for being in the room where the things were found—it was on the 5th of April, between ten and eleven o'clock—I found other articles in the room—this drinking-horn, another cap, and a silk handkerchief—this comb was found in a drawer in the room.

MRS. AUSTIN re-examined. I first saw Petty in the room when I took the policeman up to show him where I had removed the property to—I do not know how he came there—we both went up to Warren's room, and found Petty with Logden—I had not seen him there before—I saw two men go out at the street-door about an hour before, but cannot say he was one of them—Parker had given me information, which made me notice the noise there had been in the house—that was before I saw Petty in the room.

MARIA PARKER
re-examined. After the two male prisoners went out with things, Petty and another man, not Bromell, came back—I saw them as I stood at my room door—the other man ran out—I had never seen him before—he ran away from the policeman—Petty and Bromell went out about ten o'clock—it must have been past ten—I saw Petty afterwards when the policeman took him—Bromell did not come back with him—he was in custody at the time—I had not seen Petty return, as I had gone to fetch a policeman, but he must have returned.

CHARLES STEWART
re-examined. I saw Petty and another man, and Logden, in the front-room—I forgot to state that the other man was there—he escaped—he was not Bromell.
(Thomas Goodman, a stamper at Somerset House; Robert Smith, of Messrs. Barclay's bank; Robert Lewis, lighterman, Vauxball; J. Butler,
lighter man; and—Vincent, tailor, Union-street; gave Bromell a good character.

PETTY—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

WARREN—
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years.

LOGDEN—
NOT GUILTY .

1719.
WILLIAM BROMELL was again indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Samuel Lankester, about the hour of three in the night, on the 30th of March, at Lambeth, with intent to steal, and stealing therein, 1 medal, value 7s.; 1 knife, value 1s.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 4s.; 1/2 lb. weight of cigars, value 5s.; 4lbs. weight of ham, value 3s.; 1/4 lb. weight of tobacco, value 1s.; 1 1/2 pint brandy, value, 6s.; 1 shilling, 1 sixpence, 1 twopenny-piece, 100 pence, 100 halfpence, and 10 farthings; his property.

SAMUEL LANKESTER . I keep the Red Lion, in Fore-street, in the parish of Lambeth—I occupy the whole house. On the 30th of March I was the last person up, on my premises—I retired at 12 o'clock, after fastening every thing except one shutter at the back of the house, which was not fast—the window was shut—the shutter was up, and a bolt went through the window-chill to fasten it, but we could not get into the room, having lost the key—the bar-door was locked—I came down about seven in the morning—my premises were undergoing repairs, which Brown was super
intending—I found the parlour shutter taken down, the window open, and the bar-door unlocked, which was locked when I went to bed—I found several boxes in the bar had been opened—one was a club box—they bad locks to them—I missed the money and articles stated in the indictment—this silver medal I can positively speak to from its general appearance, and the letter "P" on it—it was taken from the club-box—I have no marks on this twopenny-piece and the handkerchief—I lost a cotton handkerchief of this pattern.

Cross-examined by MR. RYLAND. Q. Had you any mark on the medal? A. No—it had been in my possession about eighteen months—I speak to it with certainty—I never saw one like it—it was given into my possession when I took the house—it belongs to the club, which is still in existence—I am answerable for it to the club—I have no doubt of its being the same—I saw it safe the Monday week before, under lock and key.

JAMES LOCKYER . I am in the service of Mr. Dempster, a pawnbroker, in the Blackfriars-road. On Thursday, the 31st of March, about six o'clock in the evening, the prisoner sold me this medal—I asked him several questions—he said he had had it six months, had pawned it several times, and was tired of pawning it—I told him I thought it be
longed to the members of the Vintners' Company, and they could give him more than I could, I could give him no more than the price of old silver—he said he had had it by him six months, and would sell it—I gave him 3s. for it—he seemed surprised, and said, "Does it weigh more than half a crown?"—I said, "Yes"—I have no doubt of him, his face was dirty, and he was dressed as a waterman—I gave a description of him to an officer, the man who was sent round with the Hue and Cry, describ
ing the property stolen.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you had no doubt of him? A. From the first time I saw him—I never said I had a doubt of him—I never saw him till he sold the medal—I saw him again in rather more than a week—I did not say I believed it was him—I said I had not the least doubt—I told Mr. Trail so—we do not buy such things every day—I noticed the Vintners' arms upon it.

JEREMIAH BROWN . I am a plasterer, and live in Mill-street, Lambeth
walk. I was employed whitewashing and repairing Mr. Lankester's pre
mises—on the 31st of March I arrived there precisely at six o'clock—the clock was just about striking—I pulled my watch out—that is my time for going to work—it struck six a minute or two after I got there—I dare say my watch was correct—it is what I always go by—I was at work at the house next door—not at this house—I had then to go up the court belonging to Mr. Lankester, and found the back gate open—that was exactly at ten mi
nutes past six—I went to the water-closet, and on coming out saw Mr. Lankester's back-parlour shutters down, and also his back-door open—I did not suspect anything—I thought Mr. Lankester was up and about, as he had had soldiers billetted there two days before—the window was open—I saw nobody go in or out.

Cross-examined. Q. You did not hear the clock strike at all, did yon? A. No—I go by my watch—I looked at it—it might want a minute or two to six—I was there just before six—it was not after six—I could not say it was precisely six, or two minutes before—I regulate my watch by my landlord's clock, sometimes, not by any other clock—it was not till ten minutes after six I found the gate open—I did not give any alarm then.

MARIA PARKER . I am single, and live at No. 9, Whiting-street, Lam
beth. I saw the twopenny-piece in the room belonging to Warren, on the morning of the 5th of April—this is it—it was found in her apron-pocket, in her room—a bag was there found containing sixteen keys.

JOSEPH BROOK . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner into custody on the morning of the 5th of April, within fifty yards of No. 9, Whiting-street—I found this handkerchief in his pocket—I went to No. 9, Whit
ing-street, and found the twopenny-piece produced.

GUILTY of Larceny. Aged 20.—
Transported for Seven Years more.

1720.
SARAH DOWDELL was indicted
for unlawfully, maliciously, and feloniously assaulting
Charles Dowdell, on the 27th of March, and cast
ing and throwing loz. weight of a corrosive fluid called nitric acid, upon and over his face, and into his eyes, with intent to burn him, and whereby he was burnt.—2 other COUNTS, varying the manner of laying the charge.

CHARLES DOWDELL . I am a butcher, the prisoner is my wife. I have been separated from her rather better than three months ago, allowing her 10s. a week maintenance—I do not know where she has resided since that—I live at Exeter-place, Great Dover-road—we have been married rather better than two years, and have one child about eighteen months old—she came to me about a month after we had been separated, and wished to come back—I refused to take her back on account of her temper being so violent—she came again after that—she said nothing then about coming back, but was constantly annoying me in my business—on the 26th of March she was to receive her allowance—she generally had it on Satur
day—she came, but did not receive her money—I usually sent it by my lad

—on Sunday, the 27th, about ten o'clock at night, she came and knocked at the side shutters—I was then getting my supper—I went to the front door and saw ray wife—I am sure it was her—she asked me for the money which she did not receive on the Saturday night—I gave it to her, and as she parted away from the door, she said, "I would have you be careful, or I will have my revenge yet"—I made no reply—she went away—I went in and got my supper, after which, I changed my coat, as it was raining, and went to the Bull to get half a pint of ale—I think it must have been half-past ten or a quarter to eleven—I met her about twenty yards from my door—on seeing me, she turned, and walked in an oppo
site direction, crossed the road, and went on the opposite side of the way towards Eaton-place, which is opposite to the Bull—she was walking backwards and forwards there—I went into the Bull, at the private en
trance, the passage being rather dark, I thought she would not see me enter that door—I got half a pint of ale there—I remained in the Bull, I think not more than two minutes—as I came out she met me at the door and asked me if I was going to stand any gin—I made no reply, and while I was going away, homewards, I saw her draw her hand from under her cloak, she threw a liquid in my face, and exclaimed, "That is what I have long wished for, and now I have got my revenge"—the liquid gave me great pain, almost as if I had been scalded with hot water, a burning pain, it went into both eyes—I was obliged to shut my eyes instantly, since that I have lost the sight of one, and partly of the other—one is getting better—I was taken to Guy's Hospital—I did not see what the liquid was in.

Prisoner. Q. Did not you run from your promise in not paying me my money on Friday precisely? A. When I went to Union-hall it was on a Friday, and I paid her the 10s. in advance, and 1s. 6d. to pay her cab-hire, and it was understood I was to pay every Friday.

Prisoner. He did not fulfil his promise; I went to Union-hall, the Magistrate told me to take witnesses with me and ask him civilly for the money; he said he had got no money; I said, "What am I to do, and my poor baby is ill;" he said, "You may work for it as I do;" I said I would work, for the baby was not too bad to be left; he said, "I will send it;" and I walked away directly: I went and asked him civilly for it on Saturday night; I said, "Would you not like to see the poor child;" he said, "I neither want to see you or it;" he said he would send it, but he never did.

PETER MONTAGUE POPE . I am a surgeon of Guy's Hospital—the pro
secutor was brought there—his face was very much inflamed, and both eyes injured—it was produced by some acid—if a liquid thrown in his face produced it, I should say it was some corrosive acid—I cannot say what it was, probably nitric acid—I am certain it was some corrosive fluid—he has entirely lost the sight of one eye—the other is likely to recover, but he will never have the perfect use of it—it will be partially restored.

RICHARD WOOD . I am a policeman. I apprehended the prisoner di
rectly opposite the Bull—I told her she must go with me—she expressed her readiness to go—she said she had been in hell the last two years, and I could not take her to a worse hell, and as we went along she said she had plenty of cause to do what she had done.
Prisoner's Defence. We were married two years ago—when we came home he said, "I consider I have married you for a servant and not for a

wife, for I have another woman I like better, I shall always stick to her;" we went out and he actually came home with another woman; and the more I put up with it, the more he kicked and ill-used me—it was natural for me not to like this, for I did not think I was marrying a s—.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Three Years.

1721.
HENRY DAKEN was indicted
for stealing, in the dwelling. house of
George Gurney, on the 10th of May, at St. Mary, Newington, 30 shillings, 16 sixpences, 6 groats, 60 pence, 120 halfpence, and 750 far
things, his monies; and afterwards, about the hour of one in the night, fe
loniously and burglariously breaking out of the said dwelling-house.

GEORGE GURNEY . I keep the Red Lion, at Wal worth-road, in the parish of St. Mary, Newington. I have a drawer in my bar with a patent lock to it—I keep the silver in it, which is dropped into it in the course of the day through a space, out of the other tills, every two hours, and at night I empty it, and leave some silver on the sideboard for change—on Tuesday morning, about a quarter after two o'clock, I observed a shilling with a mark on it in the basket and left it there—I left my house that day and did not return till the following evening, Wednesday, when I had informa
tion about a quarter past seven—the basket would not be emptied in conse
quence of my absence, not until the last thing at night—the prisoner was not employed in my house at all.

THOMAS GARNER . I am barman at the Red Lion. I was at the bar on Tuesday night about twelve o'clock, and saw Mrs. Gurney clear the basket which stands in the drawer—she left out 2l. in silver for change for the following day, and put it on the sideboard loose out of the basket about ten minutes before twelve—we close the house up at twelve o'clock—I was the last that left the bar—the money was safe then—I bolted the side shop door—about five next morning I got up and found the side shop-door un
bolted and half open—it opens into the street—I missed from the sideboard the 2l. in silver—a wine decanter was removed from the shelf and put on the counter—persons could come into the yard of our house until about eleven o'clock at night—we have a coal cellar—I did not go into it over night, but the door was closed—I cannot say whether it was locked—it is in the house, in the passage leading to the yard—except the coal cellar I had examined the house, and if anybody was concealed in the house they must have been in the coal cellar—the side shop-door must have been opened from within—there were two casks placed so as not to let the door open wide—I had seen the prisoner several times during the Tuesday evening backwards and forwards in the passage leading to the yard.
Prisoner. Q. When was the last time you saw me? A. About eleven o'clock—I saw you in the tap-room about ten minutes or a quarter after eleven.
Prisoner. I was in the yard between nine and ten o'clock but not afterwards.

DAVID EVEREST . I am a sergeant of the V division of police. On Wed
nesday evening, about nine o'clock I apprehended the prisoner in a beer
shop in Hill-street, Newington—I told him I had come to take him on suspicion that he was the person who had robbed Mr. Gurney's house—he said he knew nothing about Mr. Gurney's house—he said he had no money—I searched him and found 30s. and 10d., and among it a marked shilling which I have.

Prisoner. I said I had got no money because I did not know what you came about; I did not know who you was; you did not say you had come to take me or that you was a constable. Witness. He must have known me—I was in plain clothes—I told him I apprehended him on suspicion of being concerned, or having robbed Mr. Gurney's house—Mr. Gurney was with me.

GEORGE GURNEY
re-examined. When I left the money in the basket in the drawer there was a shilling with a mark on the head—I am certain this is it, in consequence of a small T, and another T being on it, and a stamp underneath the T—I am certain I noticed these three marks on it—I took particular notice of the silver to see if any was bad, and am positive this is one of the shillings—the silver would not be disturbed till night, and then left in the bar as change for the morning.

Prisoner's Defence. The money I came by honestly; I do not see why this shilling should not be changed at the house if any body came in for change; I was in Mr. Gurney's house on Tuesday night near upon eleven o'clock; I came home about five minutes after eleven; my mother had left the door ajar; I went to bed, got up between seven and eight, came up to the Lion, stopped there most all day, and had all this money from Monday morning in my pocket.

GEORGE GURNEY
re-examined. We always keep a bag of loose silver besides—my son counts the money up—we count out 40s. for change, the rest is put into a drawer with a patent lock and locked up—when the silver was gone for change, I should resort to that which was left in the drawer—each day's change is put out for change on the following day, and if there is not sufficient we resort to the bag—this shilling might have been paid away if 1l. worth of silver was wanted—it might be given in exchange for gold, but nothing else.

THOMAS GARNER
re-examined. I had not given any change in the morning, as all that was put there for change was gone.

DAVID EVEREST
re-examined. I apprehended the prisoner at nine o'clock on Wednesday night.

THOMAS GARNER
re-examined. I had not examined the forty shillings to see the marked one—we have a bag of loose silver besides for change—the rest of the silver in the basket is left in the drawer locked up—it is counted up in pounds in the morning, and put out for change for general use—it gets into circulation in the course of the day—I saw the prisoner in the house on Wednesday, but he never changed any money.

Prisoner. I had not worked for a master for nine months, but my mother keeps a mangle; she keeps me, and gives me about 4s. a week for clothes, besides having porter's jobs; I saved the thirty shillings up.

---- DAKEN. I am the prisoner's mother—I cannot say where my son was on Tuesday night—I went to bed very tired, and ordered the door to be left ajar—I do not know how he could have thirty shillings, but he earned many a shilling of me—I have said, "You come home to-day and I will give you 2d. or 3d.," and he saved this money up to buy clothes, I firmly believe.
NOT GUILTY .
